snippet: Suffolk County pioneered buying land for farmers in the 1970s to protect it from development, but property has gotten so valuable that the land is being used for expansive lawns and equestrian centers.
abstract: Town of Southampton on Long Island pays $12.5 million for development rights to farmland in Water Mill to protect and maintain its agricultural heritage, practice pioneered by Suffolk County in 1970s; in addition to buying development rights on 33 acres, town has also bought equestrian rights, vineyard rights and restrictions on leaving land fallow for more than two years.
lead_paragraph: Suffolk County pioneered buying land for farmers in the 1970s to protect it from development, but property has gotten so valuable that the land is being used for expansive lawns and equestrian centers.

headline.main: Amid Preservation Efforts, Farmland in the Hamptons Goes for Other Uses
headline.print_headline: Amid Preservation Efforts, Farmland in the Hamptons Goes for Other Uses
